xxl.core.util

Class BitSet

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.util.BitSet
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Cloneable, Comparable<BitSet>, Convertable

    public class BitSet
extends Object
implements Cloneable, Comparable<BitSet>, Convertable
    This class is a replacement for java.util.BitSet which neither implements the interfaces Convertable nor Comparable.
    This class implements a vector of bits. Each component of the bit set has a boolean value. The bits of a BitSet are indexed by nonnegative integers. Individual indexed bits can be examined, set, or cleared. One BitSet may be used to modify the contents of another BitSet through logical AND, logical inclusive OR, and logical exclusive OR operations. Furthermore this class offers the opportunity to a convert a SDK's BitSet to an instance of this class using a default precision of 64 bit.

    By default, all bits in the set initially have the value false.

    The array bits represents the bits of a BitSet. BitSets are packed into arrays of "units." Currently a unit is a long, which consists of 64 bits, requiring 6 address bits. The ith bit is stored in bits[i/64] at bit position i % 64 (where bit position 0 refers to the most significant bit and 63 refers to the least significant bit). Every bit set has a precision, which determines the user-relevant number of bits stored by this bit set.
    Note, that the precision is related to the implementation of a bit set, so it may change with implementation. The dependence of the array bits and the user specified precision in a constructor is as follows: 

            bits = new long[ precision%64 == 0 ? (precision >>>6) : (precision>>>6)+1 ]
    The size of a bit set relates to logical length of a bit set and is defined independently of implementation.

    This class provides methods to read instances of this class from the data input and also write them to the data output. Further different methods to compare two BitSets are supported, e.g. only a specified sequence of bits can be compared or only one dimension can be compared, which is especially useful if space filling curves are represented by bit sets (e.g. z-code in spatial).

    Example usage (1): 

            BitSet bitSet = new BitSet(62);
        System.out.println("bitSet :" +bitSet);
        System.out.println("bitSet's size:" +bitSet.size());
        System.out.println("bitSet's precision:" +bitSet.precision());
        System.out.println("Setting bits: 1, 19, 23, 54");
        bitSet.set(1);
        bitSet.set(19);
        bitSet.set(23);
        bitSet.set(54);
        System.out.println("bitSet :" +bitSet);
        System.out.println("Clearing bit with index 19.");
        bitSet.clear(19);
        System.out.println("bitSet :" +bitSet);
    This first example creates a new instance of a BitSet with a precision of 62 bits. Initially all bits are false, and the size is 64 bits, because the internal used array bits has length 1.
    The bits at position 1, 19, 23 and 54 are set. After that the bit with index 19 is cleared. So the final output of the bits that are set is: {1, 23, 54}.

    Example usage (2): 

            BitSet bitSet1 = new BitSet( new long[] {first, 7, 13, 42});
        System.out.println("bitSet1: " +bitSet1);
        System.out.println("bitSet1's size:" +bitSet1.size());
        System.out.println("bitSet1's precision:" +bitSet1.precision());
        System.out.println("bitSet2 gets a clone of bitSet1.");
        BitSet bitSet2 = (BitSet)bitSet1.clone();
        System.out.println("Clearing bit with index 125 of bitSet2. ");
        bitSet2.clear(125);
        System.out.println("bitSet2: " +bitSet2);
        System.out.println("Determining first different bit between bitSet1 and bitSet2:");
        System.out.println("first different bit: " +bitSet1.diff(bitSet2));
    In this example a BitSet is created initializing the attribute bits with long values: 1l<<63(first), 7, 13, 42. So bits[0] = first, bits[1] = 7 and so on. In this case the precision is 256 (bits.length * 64) and also the size. Then bitSet1 is cloned and bit with index 125 is cleared. Therefore the following comparison returns this index as the first different bit.

    Example usage (3): 

            bitSet1 = new BitSet( new long[] {first, 7, 13, 42}, 64);
        System.out.println("bitSet1: " +bitSet1);
        System.out.println("bitSet1's size:" +bitSet1.size());
        System.out.println("bitSet1's precision:" +bitSet1.precision());
        System.out.println("result of comparison between bitSet1 and bitSet2 (precision = 64): " +bitSet1.compare(bitSet2));
        System.out.println("result of comparison between bitSet1 and bitSet2: " +bitSet1.compareTo(bitSet2));
        System.out.println("comparing only the first 20 bits: " +bitSet1.compare(bitSet2, 20));
        System.out.println("comparing the first two longs directly: " +bitSet1.compare2(bitSet2, 2));
    The last example creates nearly the same BitSet as example (2), but the precision is only 64 bits. If the two BitSets, bitSet1 and bitSet2, are compared now, the call bitSet1.compare(bitSet2) returns 0, that means that the two BitSets are equal. But there is still a difference in the bit at position 125, this difference does not matter, because the precision is set to only 64 bit. If the same comparison is fulfilled with the method compareTo the result is -1, because in this case all indices are compared. Comparing only the first 20 bits delivers the same results as compare(), but comparing the first two longs using the method compare2() returns -1, because now the comparison is fulfilled with 128 bits.
    See Also:
    DataInput, DataOutput, Cloneable, Comparable, Convertable, Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_CONVERTER

        public static SizeConverter<BitSet> DEFAULT_CONVERTER
        Converter for BitSets.

      • bits

        protected long[] bits
        The bits in this BitSet. The ith bit is stored in bits[i/64] at bit position i % 64 (where bit position 0 refers to the most significant bit and 63 refers to the least significant bit).

      • precision

        protected int precision
        The user-relevant number of bits stored by this BitSet. This number can be chosen smaller than the size of a bit set, showing that the user does not need the whole precision. This possible loss of precision results in a better performance when comparing bit sets.

      • first

        protected static final long first
        The BitSet's (first) highest bit is set to true using a 64 bit representation. All other bits are set to false.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • BitSet

        public BitSet()
        Creates a new BitSet by setting bits to null and precision to 0.

      • BitSet

        public BitSet(long l)
        Creates a new BitSet using a precision of 64 bits and an array containg only the specified long component.
        Parameters:
        l - component representing the vector of bits.

      • BitSet

        public BitSet(int precision)
        Creates a new BitSet using the given precision. The array bits is created as follows: 

                new long[ precision%64 == 0 ? (precision >>>6) : (precision>>>6)+1 ]
        That is the case, because the array's component type is long, i.e. 64 bits. So the number of bits to be stored (precision) has to be partioned in sections of 64 bits.
        Parameters:
        precision - the user-relevant number of bits stored by this BitSet.

      • BitSet

        public BitSet(BitSet b)
        Creates a new BitSet. (Copy-constructor) The new instance is created by cloning the array bits of the given BitSet b and calling the constructor BitSet(long[] bits, int precision) with this cloned array and the precision of BitSet b.
        Parameters:
        b - the BitSet to be copied.

      • BitSet

        public BitSet(long[] bits)
        Creates a new BitSet using the specified array and precision that results in bits.length*64.
        Parameters:
        bits - the array representing a vector of bits.

      • BitSet

        public BitSet(long[] bits,
              int precision)
        Creates a new BitSet using the given array and precision.
        Parameters:
        bits - the array representing a vector of bits.
        precision - the user-relevant number of bits to be stored by this BitSet.

      • BitSet

        public BitSet(BitSet bitSet)
        Creates a new BitSet using the given BitSet. A default precision of 64 bits is used. So the created bit set is absolutely identical to the given bit set in each bit.
        Parameters:
        bitSet - an instance of BitSet.

    • Method Detail

      • getSize

        public static int getSize(int precision)
        Returns the serialization size of a BitSet of a certain precision.
        Parameters:
        precision - Precision of the BitSet.
        Returns:
        Size in bytes.

      • convert

        public static BitSet convert(BitSet bitSet)
        The given SDK's BitSet is converted to a BitSet using a default precision of 64 bits. So the resulting bit set is absolutely identical to the given bit set in each bit.
        Parameters:
        bitSet - input SDK's BitSet
        Returns:
        copy of input BitSet as BitSet

      • precision

        public int precision()
        Returns the BitSet's precision, i.e. the number of bits stored by this BitSet.
        Returns:
        the precision of this BitSet.

      • clone

        public Object clone()
        Cloning this BitSet produces a new BitSet that is equal to it. The clone of the bit set is another bit set that has exactly the same bits set to true as this bit set and the same precision.

        Overrides the clone method of Object. The copy-constructor BitSet(BitSet) is called.

        Overrides:
        clone in class Object
        Returns:
        a clone of this bit set.

      • set

        public void set(int bitIndex)
        Sets the bit specified by the index to true.
        Parameters:
        bitIndex - a bit index.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the specified index is negative.

      • get

        public boolean get(int bitIndex)
        Returns the value of the bit with the specified index. The value is true if the bit with the index bitIndex is currently set in this BitSet; otherwise, the result is false.
        Parameters:
        bitIndex - the bit index.
        Returns:
        the value of the bit with the specified index.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the specified index is negative.

      • clear

        public void clear(int bitIndex)
        Sets the bit specified by the index to false.
        Parameters:
        bitIndex - the index of the bit to be cleared.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the specified index is negative.

      • size

        public int size()
        Returns the number of bits of space actually in use by this BitSet to represent bit values. The size is determined by bits.length<<6, i.e. bits.length*64, because the array's component type is long.
        Returns:
        the size of this bit set.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns a string representation of this bit set. For every index for which this BitSet contains a bit in the set state, the decimal representation of that index is included in the result. Such indeces are listed in order from lowest to highest, separated by ",$nbsp;" (a comma and a space) and surrounded by braces, resulting in the usual mathematical notation for a set of integers.

        Overrides the toString method of Object.

        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        a string representation of this bit set.

      • toString2

        public String toString2()
        Alternate visualization of this String.
        Returns:
        resulting string

      • read

        public void read(DataInput in)
          throws IOException
        Reads the state (the attributes) for an object of this class from the specified data input and restores the calling object. The state of the object before calling read will be lost.
        In this case an Integer object is read at first, which contains the information about the BitSet's precision, i.e. the number of bits stored by this BitSet. After that the array bits is created and filled up with bits.length Long objects read from the specified data input.
        Specified by:
        read in interface Convertable
        Parameters:
        in - the stream to read data from in order to restore the object.
        Throws:
        IOException - if I/O errors occur.

      • write

        public void write(DataOutput out)
           throws IOException
        Writes the state (the attributes) of the calling object to the specified data output. At first an Integer object is written representing the BitSet's precision, i.e. the number of bits stored by this BitSet. After that the long array bits is written to the data output by calling the data output's method writeLong for each component of the array.
        Specified by:
        write in interface Convertable
        Parameters:
        out - the stream to write the state (the attributes) of the object to.
        Throws:
        IOException - includes any I/O exceptions that may occur.

      • diff

        public int diff(BitSet b)
        Compares two BitSets and returns the index of the first bit that differs starting at bit index 0. A maximum of Integer.MAX_VALUE bits will be compared.
        Parameters:
        b - the BitSet to be compared with the BitSet calling this method.
        Returns:
        the index of the first bit that differs.
        See Also:
        diff(BitSet, int)

      • diff

        public int diff(BitSet b,
                int nobits)
        Compares two BitSets concerning the specified number of bits nobits and returns the index of the first bit that differs starting at bit index 0. A maximum of min{precision, b.precision, nobits} bits will be compared.
        Parameters:
        b - the BitSet to be compared with the BitSet calling this method.
        nobits - the maximum number of bits to be compared.
        Returns:
        the index of the first bit that differs.

      • compare

        public int compare(BitSet b)
        Compares the calling Bitset with the given BitSet b. The comparsion starts at bit index 0. A maximum of min{precision, b.precision} bits will be compared. This method returns a negative if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet b, a positive value if BitSet b is smaller, otherwise 0 is returned.
        Parameters:
        b - the BitSet to be compared with the BitSet calling this method.
        Returns:
        a negative value if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet b, a positive value if BitSet b is smaller, else 0 is returned.
        See Also:
        compare(BitSet, int, int, int)

      • compare

        public int compare(BitSet b,
                   int nobits)
        Compares the calling Bitset with the given BitSet b in the specified number of bits nobits. The comparsion starts at bit index 0. A maximum of min{precision, b.precision, nobits} bits will be compared. This method returns a negative if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet b, a positive value if BitSet b is smaller, otherwise 0 is returned.
        Parameters:
        b - the BitSet to be compared with the BitSet calling this method.
        nobits - the maximum number of bits to be compared.
        Returns:
        a negative value if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet b, a positive value if BitSet b is smaller, else 0 is returned.
        See Also:
        compare(BitSet, int, int, int)

      • compare

        public int compare(BitSet b,
                   int nobits,
                   int dim,
                   int maxDim)
        Compares two BitSets with regard to only one dimension dim.
        This method is implemented as follows: 

                int bitIndex = dim;
        for(nobits = Math.min( Math.min(precision,b.precision),nobits ); bitIndex < nobits; bitIndex += maxDim)
                if( get(bitIndex) != b.get(bitIndex) )
                        return (get(bitIndex)?1:0) - (b.get(bitIndex)?1:0);
        return 0;
        A maximum of min{precision, b.precision, nobits} bits will be compared. The bits at bit index bitIndex will be compared starting with bitIndex = dim. Each time the comparison of two bits delivers true the bitIndex is incremented by maxDim.
        This method returns a negative if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet b, a positive value if BitSet b is smaller, otherwise 0 is returned.
        Parameters:
        b - the BitSet to be compared with the BitSet calling this method.
        nobits - the maximum number of bits to be compared.
        dim - the bit index the comparison starts.
        maxDim - a value which is added after each comparsion of two bits to the current bit index.
        Returns:
        a negative value if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet b, a positive value if BitSet b is smaller, else 0 is returned.
        See Also:
        xxl.core.spatial

      • compare2

        public int compare2(BitSet b,
                    int noLongs)
        Compares the calling Bitset with the given BitSet b in terms of their components, i.e. the longs will be compared directly. The given parameter noLongs, number of longs, specifies the maximum number of long components of the array bits to be compared. So this method is faster than compare(BitSet,int).
        Parameters:
        b - the BitSet to be compared with the BitSet calling this method.
        noLongs - the number of longs to be compared, i.e. bits[0], ..., bits[noLongs] will be compared at the most.
        Returns:
        a negative value if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet b, a positive value if BitSet b is smaller, else 0 is returned.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if noLongs is negative or it is larger than min{bits.length-1, b.bits.length-1}.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(BitSet bs)
        Compares the calling Bitset with the given Object o casted to a BitSet. The comparison returns a negative if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet o, a positive value if BitSet o is smaller, otherwise 0 is returned.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<BitSet>
        Parameters:
        bs - the BitSet to be compared with the BitSet calling this method.
        Returns:
        a negative value if this (the calling) BitSet is smaller than the given BitSet o, a positive value if BitSet o is smaller, else 0 is returned.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object o)
        Tests if this is equal to the BitSet which is given as parameter.
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        o - second BitSet object.
        Returns:
        true iff both BitSets are equal.

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns a hash code for the BitSet.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        the hash code.

      • or

        public void or(BitSet bitSet)
        Performs a logical OR of this bit set with the specified bit set. This bit set is modified so that a bit in it has the value true if and only if it either already had the value true or the corresponding bit in the bit set argument has the value true.
        Note, this BitSet's capacity may change when executing this method, because the two BitSet are set to the larger length of the internal used array bits, so this array will have the following length: 


                Math.max(bits.length, bitSet.bits.length)
        Parameters:
        bitSet - a bit set the operation should be fulfilled with.

      • and

        public void and(BitSet bitSet)
        Performs a logical AND of this target bit set with the argument bit set. This bit set is modified so that each bit in it has the value true if and only if it both initially had the value true and the corresponding bit in the bit set argument also had the value true.
        Note, this BitSet's capacity may change when executing this method, because the two BitSet are set to the larger length of the internal used array bits, so this array will have the following length: 


                Math.max(bits.length, bitSet.bits.length)
        Parameters:
        bitSet - a bit set the operation should be fulfilled with.

      • xor

        public void xor(BitSet bitSet)
        Performs a logical XOR of this bit set with the bit set argument. This bit set is modified so that a bit in it has the value true if and only if one of the following statements holds:
        • The bit initially has the value true, and the corresponding bit in the argument has the value false.
        • The bit initially has the value false, and the corresponding bit in the argument has the value true.

        Note, this BitSet's capacity may change when executing this method, because the two BitSet are set to the larger length of the internal used array bits, so this array will have the following length: 


                Math.max(bits.length, bitSet.bits.length)
        Parameters:
        bitSet - a bit set the operation should be fulfilled with.

      • not

        public void not()
        Performs a logical NOT of this bit set. This bit set is modified so that every bit is negated, i.e. a set bit is cleared and a bit set to false is set to true.
